Identification of peptides as alternative recycling tools via phage surface display – How biology supports Geosciences
F.L. Lederer⁎, R. Braun, L.M. Schöne, K. Pollmann Helmholtz-Zentrum Dresden-Rossendorf, Helmholtz Institute Freiberg for Resource Technology, Department of Biotechnology, Dresden, Germany
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: LaPO4:Ce3+,Tb3+ Phage surface display Peptide Recycling Rare earth element
A B S T R A C T
The application of biological tools in Geosciences such as bacteria or microbial products that mobilize metallic components raises increasing interest in classical mining industries. Today, 10% of the total copper production in Chile originated from bioleaching operations (Gentina and Acevedo, 2016). However, the application of biological tools is limited due to poor specificity, complex material composition and heterogenous particle size. New studies focus on smaller biological components such as peptides with higher material specificity to mobilize and recycle materials of interest.
End-of-life electronic products like smart phones or compact fluorescent lamps (CFL) contain a wide variety of precious elements in very low concentrations. Currently, no cost-efficient and environmentally friendly technology exists for the separation and recycling of the majority of high-tech industry supporting elements such as the rare earth element (REE) Lanthanum phosphate (LAP) from electronic scrap. The focus of this project was the identification of peptides with high specificity for the rare earth mineral LAP, a component of CFL, for future material recycling. By using a biological method called phage surface display and the random PVIII phage peptide library f88.4/Cys6, the phage-bound peptide TSTQCPSHIRACLKKR was identified and characterized as not only an efficient LAP binder, which is furthermore able to discriminate between LAP and other components of fluorescent lamps. The application of phage particles displaying the recombinant PVIII fused peptide TSTQCPSHIRACLKKR in recycling processes is not possible due to limited scale-up, critical public perception, low biological efficiency and fast mutation rates in phage particles. Future applications will be based on peptides that are stable under a variety of challenging conditions such as heat, varying pH or in the presence of toxic scrap components. The development of peptide-based separation tools represents a new way of recycling of electronic scrap.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Rare earth elements (REE) are 17 different metals such as lanthanum, cerium, europium and terbium that are essential components of smart phones, flat screens, compact fluorescent lamps (CFL) and wind power plants. REE are key mineral resources for the fast growing green technology and in many future technologies (Sprecher et al., 2014). The rapid development of new technologies and the complexity of our daily-life electronic devices are forcing the European Union and other industrial nations to ensure the availability of economically essential elements (Dodson et al., 2015; Frenzel et al., 2017; UNEP, 2013). The majority of these elements are currently mined and extracted from primary ore (Dodson et al., 2012). However, rising costs of imported materials combined with an increased motivation to utilize
nationally sourced materials has shifted attention towards recycling of electronic scrap that often contains higher contents of valuable materials than the original mineral ore (UNEP, 2013).
To save the dwindling supply of natural resources, recycling is an important approach without serious impact on the environment. In contrast, the mining based extraction of primary resources is often accompanied by its harmful impact to the environment (Schüler et al., 2011). Recently, several countries have increased recycling rates of electronic products using different approaches such as optimizing the product design or progress in recycling technologies (Hagelüken et al., 2016). However, recycling rates are still low. High recycling rates only exist for precious metals and special metals and are mainly used for ferrous and base metals such as iron, nickel, copper or aluminum (UNEP, 2013). earths due to economic and technical limitations; for example in 2011 it was estimated that only 1% of rare earths used in electronic devices were recycled (Binnemans et al., 2013). The new commission report on critical raw materials and the circular economy of the European Union talks about 7% recycling quote for light REEs and 6% recycling quote for heavy REEs (EU Commission report, 2018).
Compact fluorescent lamps are widely used devices that reduce the energy need. In addition to other components like glass, metals, plastics, and mercury, CFL contain fluorescent phosphor powder. This fluorescent phosphor powder contains 10–20wt% fluorescent phosphor composed of barium magnesium aluminate, cerium magnesium aluminate (CAT), lanthanum phosphate (LAP), halophosphate and yttrium oxide (YOX). Currently, compact fluorescent lamps are collected separately from other electronic scraps and the mercury containing lamp powder is stored in special deposits until efficient recycling tools have been developed. This project involves the use of the biological technology “phage surface display (PSD)” for the development of a new and efficient biomolecule-based CFL recycling process.
Phage surface display is a promising method helping to identify peptides with a high specificity for special target materials. Peptides are short proteins composed of amino acids (See Table 1). Traditionally, this method was applied in medical and pharmaceutical research to study molecular biological mechanisms involving protein-protein and protein-non-protein interactions (Vodnik et al., 2011). In earlier studies, Curtis and coworkers developed a new PSD technology for the identification of peptides that discriminate between chalcopyrite, sphalerite and enargite to revolutionize primary ore separation processes (Curtis et al., 2009; Curtis et al., 2011; Curtis et al., 2013; Curtis et al., 2017; Dunbar et al., 2008). Other groups used neodymium ions as target material for the PSD technology and identified phage clones displaying peptides with a specific affinity for Nd3+ rather than Fe3+ (Sawada et al., 2016). Earlier studies of our group focused on the identification of phage display derived peptides that bind with high affinity and specificity to LAP and CAT (Lederer et al., 2017; Braun et al., 2018). The first promising LAP binding phage clone derived from the phage peptide library f88.4/LX-4 (Lederer et al., 2017). PVIII peptides displayed in LX-4 phage libraries are eight amino acids in length and have a randomized amino acid composition with two fixed cysteines at position two and seven (Bonnycastle et al., 1996). The promising CAT binding phage clone derived from the phage peptide library f88.4/Cys4, displays 12 randomized amino acids per recombinant modified PVIII peptide with two fixed cysteines at position five and ten (Braun et al., 2018). The expression of recombinant peptides by the f88.4 vector differs between ≤1% of the total PVIII for larger peptides to up to 15% for shorter ones (Bonnycastle et al., 1996).
In this study, the random PVIII phage library f88.4/Cys6 (14 randomized amino acids and two fixed cysteines at position five and twelve) was screened for peptide sequences that bind selectively to the fluorescent phosphor LAP (LaPO4:Ce3+,Tb3+). The combination of displaying at least 40 copies of the binding peptides per phage and a diversity of 2.7× 108 different phage in one phage library provided suitable conditions to identify phage bound peptides with the highest specificity for special targets (Bonnycastle et al., 1996). After several rounds of enrichment, phage clones containing a surface peptide that
bound specifically and extraordinarily well to LAP were identified and characterized.
This study has been using phage surface display as a key method to develop peptides with high specificity for particular inorganic targets in electronic scrap. Lanthanum phosphate was used as a target material of economic interest to validate the application possibilities of the phage display method. The identification of peptides with high specificity for one component in the fluorescent powder of compact fluorescent lamps shows the power of phage display for geobiotechnological purposes and potentially initiates a new way of recycling. Aim of this study was the identification of rare earth element specific peptides that can be used in future applications for rare earth recycling.

sections.heading: 2.1. Phage library and bacterial strain
sections.text: The f88.4/Cys6 16-mer peptide library (Creative Biolabs, Shirley, NY) was used for the identification of LaPO4:Ce3+, Tb3+-binding peptides according to the manufacturer’s instructions. The Cys6 library consists of phage displaying peptides at the N-terminus of the major coat protein PVIII. The phage vector f88.4 used for production of the Cys6 library results in hybrid virions, which consist of both wild-type and recombinant PVIII. The recombinant PVIII peptides possess the amino acid sequence SFAA(X)4C(X)6C(X)4PAE, with X being the randomized amino acid. Each f88.4 hybrid virion displays up to ∼15% of the recombinant PVIII (Henry et al., 2015). The bacterial strain used for PVIII modified phage amplification was Escherichia coli K91 (λ− Su− thi Hfr Cavelli) (Bonnycastle et al., 1996; Smith and Scott, 1993).

sections.heading: 2.2. Phage surface display for LAP binding peptides
sections.text:
Terbium (13mol percent) and cerium (27mol percent) doped lanthanum phosphate (Leuchtstoffe Breitungen GmbH, Germany) is part of the fluorescent powder of compact fluorescent lamps. LAP was used for the selection of specific binding peptides from the recombinant phage peptide library f88.4/Cys6. Experiments were performed as previously described (Curtis et al., 2009; Lederer et al., 2017). Samples (20mg) of LAP sized 3–7 µm were washed with TRIS-buffered saline (TBS) and blocked with PBS containing bovine serum albumin (BSA, 10mg/ml). The pretreated minerals were washed three times with TBS and were subsequently incubated with ∼1.3×1012 phage particles displaying 2.7×108 different randomized peptides. Removal of weakly bound phage was achieved by subsequent repeated washing with TBS containing 0.1% Tween-20 (TBST). Elution of strong binding phage was carried out using glycine buffer (0.2M Glycine HCl, pH 2.2, 1 mg/mL BSA) or alternatively achieved by incubating the material directly with freshly prepared E. coli K91 cells. Amplification of phage was achieved by infection of freshly prepared E. coli K91 (Barbas et al., 2004). Infected cells were cultivated and induced with IPTG. Amplified phage particles were isolated and precipitated via PEG precipitation as described elsewhere (Barbas et al., 2004). Three rounds of bio-panning were performed with increasing concentration of Tween 20 in binding and washing buffer to select strongly binding phage. Following the bio-

panning cycles, random plaques of infected E. coli K91 cells were used as template for PCR amplification. The selective amplification of DNA fragments was performed using the NEB Taq DNA polymerase (New England Biolabs). The PCR reaction started with an initial denaturation at 95 °C for 2min. Afterwards 35 reaction cycles followed starting with 30 s of denaturation 95 °C, followed by 30 s of primer annealing at 55 °C and ending with 45 s of elongation at 72 °C. The oligonucleotide primers had the following sequences: (forward) 5′-GCTCTAAATCGGGGG AGCT−3′; (reverse) 5′-CATAAGCTAGCTTAAAAAAAAGCCCGC−3′. With the final elongation step (2min, 72 °C) the PCR reaction was finished and the results were analyzed via agarose gel electrophoresis. Amplified PCR products (1 µL each) were used as template in a DNAsequencing reaction using a BigDye® Terminator Cycle Sequencing Kit (Applied Biosystems) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. The primer sequence used for Sanger sequencing was 5′-AGTAGCAGAAGC CTGAAGA−3′ (User Manual, f88-fuseTM Phage display peptide library kit, Creative Biolabs). After purification of the DNA sequencing products, the samples were analyzed using the Applied Biosystems 3730XL DNA sequencer at St. Paul’s Hospital, Vancouver, CA. The recombinant peptide sequences were analyzed using the Chromas program.

sections.heading: 2.3. Binding assay for LAP-binding peptides
sections.text: Pre-identified phage derived from single clone amplification were characterized for their ability to bind to individual components of fluorescent lamp powder and the non-processed enargite (Cu3AsS4) as a negative control and to quantify the selective binding behavior. Components tested were Y2O3:Eu3+ (YOX), LaPO4:Ce3+, Tb3+ (LAP) and enargite. Mineral preparation, phage production and binding studies were performed as described elsewhere (Lederer et al., 2017). Mineral dispersions were incubated together with the phage and subsequently repeatedly washed, resulting in the removal of weakly bound phage. Phage concentrations in input and eluate were determined and compared to the binding behavior of wild-type fd-tet phage (obtained from Dr. Jamie Scott, Simon Fraser University, Burnaby, BC). The binding ability of different phage is calculated from the ratio of bound phage in eluate compared to the phage input concentration normalized against the wild-type phage values.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
The random PVIII peptide phage library f88.4/Cys6 was screened to identify phage clones displaying peptide sequences that bind specifically to the fluorescent phosphor LAP. The intended application of these peptides is ultimately to be utilized in the separation and recycling of LAP from the other lamp phosphor components of compact fluorescent lamps. In earlier studies, we reported the identification of the LAP binding peptide RCQYPLCS sourced from the f88.4/LX-4 library. Using alanine scanning mutagenesis, the phage peptide binding was improved significantly (Lederer et al., 2017). In the current study, the naturally better binding phage bound peptide FL 606 is presented. Both, the phage clone FL 464 and FL 606 were characterized for their binding to different minerals to prove their specificity for their target material, LAP.
3.1. Identification and characterization of LAP selective phage
Following three rounds of bio-panning and biological elution (BE) with E. coli K91 or chemical elution (CE) with glycine buffer, thirty individual plaques were picked, the phage DNA was amplified and the DNA sequences of the encoded pVIII genes were determined. The sequencing results presented 12 different sequences; the most frequently occurring amino acid sequence was TSTQCPSHIRACLKKR (FL 606) with 9 out of 30 analyzed plaques. Other peptides occurred 1–2 times out of 30 analyzed plaques. Table 2 shows the amino acid compositions, the number of functional amino acid residues, and the calculated
isoelectric point of the six most occurring peptides and the earlier published LAP binding peptide RCQYPLCS (f88.4/LX-4 peptide phage library, (Lederer et al., 2017)). The presence of basic and hydrophobic amino acids represents obvious similarities between each of the seven peptides. The occurrence of acidic amino acids was rare with only one identified in FL 591, FL 594 and FL 601, respectively. However, the presence of primarily polar amino acids is a consistent characteristic of all the identified mineral binding peptide sequences. The most promising peptide FL 606 is characterized by five N-terminal uncharged polar amino acids (Table 2, green) and five C-terminal positively charged amino acids (Table 2, red). Earlier studies have discussed the strong interaction of peptides containing domains with charged and uncharged polar amino acids with inorganic surfaces (Curtis et al., 2009; Lederer et al., 2017; Willett et al., 2005). Cetinel et al. (2012) discussed the positive effect of strong platinum particle binders that contain threonine, serine and glutamine which also occur in the Nterminal of FL 606 (Cetinel et al., 2012). Other scientists additionally discussed the important roles of lysine, histidine (Milovic and Kostic, 2001, 2002) and cysteine (Zhu and Kostic, 1992) for the binding of inorganic targets (Cetinel et al., 2012). Determination of the importance of cysteine for the interaction is complicated, as all peptides in the LX-4 library possess two central cysteines, separated by six randomized amino acids. Lysines (2-C-terminal), a histidine (1-central) and cysteines (2-central) occur in FL 606 (TSTQCPSHIRACLKKR). The theoretical isoelectric points (pI) of the seven analyzed sequences are shown in Table 2 and range from 7.09 and 10.05, whereas the peptide FL 606 displays the highest pI. The results of our studies with the best LAP binding phage indicate that the combination of charged and uncharged amino acids at opposite ends of the peptide with no charged amino acids in between is important for the strong LAP binding.

sections.heading: 3.2. Binding studies
sections.text:
A selection of clones from the third round of bio-panning was used for further binding studies. The phage clone expressing the peptide TSTQCPSHIRACLKKR (FL 606) bound to LAP 364 times greater than the wild-type phage. Four of the phage tested had ≥19-fold better binding to LAP than the wild-type phage (Fig. 1, Table 2). The recombinant PVIII proteins are displayed in approximately 40–600 copies on the surface of the f88.4 hybrid virion that displays about 4000 wildtype PVIII proteins (Bonnycastle et al., 1996). Binding studies with individual phage amplification batches identified big differences of the phage clone FL 606 binding behavior to LAP. As discussed earlier this is potentially a result of variability in the number of displayed binding peptides on the phage envelope, which would contribute to differences in target binding (Lederer et al., 2017). The loss of a small number of LAP particles during the treatment of LAP minerals in several washing steps may contribute to different binding results as well.
The net charge of the peptides at pH 7.5 were calculated to be +3.7 (FL 606), +1.6 (FL 591), −0.3 (FL 592), +0.7 (FL 594), +0.6 (FL 601), +2.7 (FL 602) and +0.6 (FL 464). Earlier studies discussed the theory that the positively charged amino acids of the displayed peptides interact directly with the negatively charged LAP mineral particles (zeta potential of −29mV, (Lederer et al., 2017)) through electrostatic interactions, as at pH 7.5 the basic amino acids will be protonated (Curtis et al., 2017). Willett et al. (2005) have discussed the different adhesion mechanisms of peptides to inorganic surfaces. The side chains of the amino acids define these interactions (Willett et al., 2005). Other studies have published results that claim hydrophobic forces to dominate in adhesion between amino acids and inorganic surfaces. It was discussed that the influence of the peptide sequence, the binding environment (pH), and the nature of the surface (hydrophobic, hydrophilic) control the adhesion moment (Razvag et al., 2013). The surface of the LAP particles is very complex and exhibits multiple options for peptide interaction. The underlying adhesion mechanism is probably a combination of different effects supporting the peptide interaction.
However, currently there is no information published on how the peptide is interacting with the material surface of LAP and if the sequence uses a specific folding that is expected for peptides containing two cysteine residues.
All tested phage had a higher binding efficiency against the tested materials than the wild-type phage, indicating that bio-panning allowed for the successful selection of peptide sequences with high affinity to LAP.
It was expected that the biological elution with competent E. coli K91 cells would be able to mobilize and detect stronger LAP binding phage. However, results of the biological and chemical elution as depicted in Table 2 show the obviously more powerful mobilization of the best LAP binding phage (FL 606 and FL 464) via chemical elution with low pH glycine buffer.
As the goal of this study was to identify peptides that could distinguish between LAP and other minerals, the binding behavior of the most promising phage clones FL 606 and FL 464 was determined for the other components of fluorescent lamps, the fluorescent phosphor Y2O3:Eu3+ (YOX) and the mineral Cu3AsS4 (enargite) (Fig. 2). While YOX is prepared in multiple processing steps as a lamp phosphor component, enargite is a non-processed material. We were interested if the peptides distinguish strongly between the different lamp phosphor components or if similar charges and processing steps influence a target binding as well. Enargite was used as a negative control. When compared with the binding to YOX and enargite, FL 606 and FL 464 were shown to be highly specific for LAP (Fig. 2). The binding affinity of FL 606 and FL 464 to YOX and enargite was close to the binding behavior to wild-type phage.
3.3. Instability of phage amplification
Compared to the amplification of wild-type phage in the E. coli host
strain, phage amplification was lower for phage FL 606 and FL 464 potentially due to the peptide composition and the expression of longer PVIII proteins. However, in consecutive amplification experiments, the yield of the phage clones in the E. coli host strain increased with every amplification round. Concomitant, these amplified phage clones show a drastically reduced binding behavior to their target material ending with a binding comparable to the wild-type phage binding (Pollmann et al,. 2018). Most probably, mutations in the phage genome were the reason for the accelerated amplification. The amplified phage clones had lost their ability to display the recombinant modified PVIII. Without the recombinant PVIII peptide expression, the E. coli metabolism was able to express more phage particles at the same time. Growing temperature was the driving factor in the mutation rate of the phage clones. To reduce the mutation potential, the phage clones were amplified at room temperature (FL 464) and 30 °C (FL 606). These temperatures combine the lowest mutation risk with the best binding results. However, due to the instable phage genome that is prone to mutations, future materials should contain the identified peptides rather than phage particles.

sections.heading: 4. Outlook
sections.text: Goal of this study was the application of REE specific peptides in different recycling processes. The most promising peptides will be both, chemically synthesized and produced via heterologous (recombinant) expression. These peptides can also be modified to immobilize them on inorganic carriers like magnetic beads for the separation of LAP from other fluorescence phosphors in special separation processes (Vreuls et al., 2011). An inexpensive production of peptides via heterologous expression is essential for their later application as tools in recycling processes.

sections.heading: 4.1. Heterologous expression of promising peptides
sections.text:
Efficient recombinant expression and production of promising peptide sequences is of high commercial interest since chemical synthesis of peptides, primarily accomplished by solid phase synthesis, remains not only limited to small peptides in very low quantities but is also prohibitively expensive. The peptide moieties identified in this work possess a maximum length of only 16 amino acids, implying challenging difficulties for heterologous expression because of sensitivity to proteolytic degradation, low expression levels and poor recovery yields (Zorko et al., 2009). The strategic selection of fusion partner proteins facilitates production and downstream processing. Specific peptides with enhanced affinity for purification or for decreased proteolysis are necessary for economically feasible production (Chen et al., 2013). Accompanying this work, we were able to construct a simple and robust expression system, which is presently being evaluated for its efficiency and compared to chemical synthesis (Braun et al., 2017). Special consideration of the protein structure was taken

into account, because folding of peptides, displayed in phage surface display, may be strongly correlated to the correct folding of the adjacent part of the phage coat protein. The complex nature of the transport and assembly of M13KE phage proteins leads to a multilayered PVIII coat protein. PVIII, although only comprising of 73 aa including a 23 aa signal peptide, shows a secondary structure consisting of two large helices. Furthermore, these helices are partly hydrophobic to facilitate the transport and assembly process of the phage. For heterologous expression various fusion proteins were developed that include truncated parts of PVIII. As proteins interact with manifold materials, we included a cleavage site adjacent to the affinity tag (Fig. 3). This design results in material-interacting fusion proteins, which are as small as possible, minimizing nonspecific interactions and misfolding.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
The goal of this study was the identification of peptides with high specificity and affinity for individual lamp phosphor components for the future development of new rare earth element recycling processes from electronic scrap. The identification of the peptide TSTQCPSHIRACLKKR displaying phage clone FL 606 with specificity for
LaPO4:Ce3+, Tb3+ has been achieved in this study. The phage clone FL 606 was identified using the peptide library f88.4/Cys6. In comparison to the earlier identified LAP specific phage, clone FL 464 (RCQYPLCS) derived from the PVIII phage peptide library f88.4/LX-4, this clone binds LAP with a higher affinity (Lederer et al., 2017). The PSD technology is suitable to identify peptide motifs, which bind to their target materials with high affinity and selectivity. In particular, target material selection is nearly unlimited, promising wide application across different areas. We therefore propose the general usability of phage surface display in resource technologies, opening completely new fields for biotechnological advances. The application of phage particles in recycling processes is not possible due to safety rules, mutation risks and missing economic usability. Future separation processes of primary or secondary resources will be potentially based on phage derived peptides combined with already well-established processes such as flotation or magnetic separation. These approaches are superior to conventional resource recovery technology especially comparing their ecological impact as nearly no critical waste is produced and no harmful chemicals are needed (Binnemans et al., 2015). However, further characterization is needed to quantify process conditions, reusability and scale-up possibilities. Furthermore, for economic reasons
production of peptides most likely needs to be done by heterologous expression, which is simple and efficient (Braun et al., 2017). In summary, we present a promising way for the identification of inorganic target binding peptides with the potential to be used in future separation processes for primary and secondary resources.

metadata.abstractText: The application of biological tools in Geosciences such as bacteria or microbial products that mobilize metallic components raises increasing interest in classical mining industries. Today, 10% of the total copper production in Chile originated from bioleaching operations (Gentina and Acevedo, 2016). However, the application of biological tools is limited due to poor specificity, complex material composition and heterogenous particle size. New studies focus on smaller biological components such as peptides with higher material specificity to mobilize and recycle materials of interest. End-of-life electronic products like smart phones or compact fluorescent lamps (CFL) contain a wide variety of precious elements in very low concentrations. Currently, no cost-efficient and environmentally friendly technology exists for the separation and recycling of the majority of high-tech industry supporting elements such as the rare earth element (REE) Lanthanum phosphate (LAP) from electronic scrap. The focus of this project was the identification of peptides with high specificity for the rare earth mineral LAP, a component of CFL, for future material recycling. By using a biological method called phage surface display and the random PVIII phage peptide library f88.4/Cys6, the phage-bound peptide TSTQCPSHIRACLKKR was identified and characterized as not only an efficient LAP binder, which is furthermore able to discriminate between LAP and other components of fluorescent lamps. The application of phage particles displaying the recombinant PVIII fused peptide TSTQCPSHIRACLKKR in recycling processes is not possible due to limited scale-up, critical public perception, low biological efficiency and fast mutation rates in phage particles. Future applications will be based on peptides that are stable under a variety of challenging conditions such as heat, varying pH or in the presence of toxic scrap components.
